DataElement.preferredName: Lung Precancerous Condition Histopathologic Examination Outcome
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The result of a precancerous lung tissue examination using light or electron microscopy and employing cytochemical and immunocytochemical stain.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border._Pathological processes that tend eventually to become malignant. (From Dorland, 27th ed)_The microscopic study of characteristic tissue abnormalities by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has but two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border. SYN pulmo.

Concepts.definition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

Property.preferredDefinition: Pathological processes that tend eventually to become malignant. (From Dorland, 27th ed):The microscopic study of characteristic tissue abnormalities by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

Concepts.definition: A pathological process with signs indicating it may become cancerous.  Representative examples include leukoplakia, dysplastic nevus, actinic keratosis, xeroderma pigmentosum, and intraepithelial neoplasia.
The microscopic study of characteristic tissue abnormalities by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Top level term which includes Biological Markers, Risk Factors, and Prognostic Factors.

DataElementConcept.origin: MCL:Molecular and Cellular Characterization of Screened Lesions
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 4/25/19 jk released/qualified per review by Sarah M. 4/7/19 jk created for MCL PCA Lung.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border._The microscopic study of characteristic tissue abnormalities by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains._The result of an action.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding indicating the presence of severe cellular atypia associated with severe architectural changes in a tissue sample.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding indicating the presence of severe cellular atypia associated with severe architectural changes in a tissue sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding indicating the presence of moderate cellular atypia associated with moderate architectural changes in a tissue sample.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding indicating the presence of moderate cellular atypia associated with moderate architectural changes in a tissue sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding indicating the presence of mild cellular atypia associated with mild architectural changes in a tissue sample.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding indicating the presence of mild cellular atypia associated with mild architectural changes in a tissue sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A solitary adenocarcinoma arising from the lung measuring 3 cm or less. It is characterized by a predominantly lepidic pattern and 5 mm or less invasion in greatest dimension. It is usually a non-mucinous adenocarcinoma, but rarely may be mucinous.

Concepts.definition: A solitary adenocarcinoma arising from the lung and measuring 3 cm or less in size. It is characterized by a predominantly lepidic pattern and 5 mm or less invasion in greatest dimension. It is usually a non-mucinous adenocarcinoma, but rarely may be mucinous.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated definition to match current NCIt. 4.10.19 mc

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A multifocal neoplastic process in the lung parenchyma characterized by the proliferation of atypical alveolar epithelial cells without the presence of significant chronic inflammation.

Concepts.definition: A preinvasive lesion in the lung. It is characterized by the presence of a small, localized proliferation of mildly to moderately atypical type II pneumocytes and/or Clara cells lining alveolar walls and sometimes respiratory bronchioles.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A localized non-invasive adenocarcinoma of the lung measuring 3 cm or less. It is characterized by a pure lepidic growth pattern and the lack of stromal, vascular, or pleural invasion.

Concepts.definition: A localized non-invasive adenocarcinoma of the lung measuring 3 cm or less. It is characterized by a pure lepidic growth pattern and the lack of stromal, vascular, or pleural invasion.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Lung Squamous Cell Carcinoma In Situ

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Lung Squamous Cell Carcinoma In Situ
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A preinvasive bronchial neoplastic lesion affecting the squamous epithelium. It is characterized by the absence of progression of maturation from base to luminal surface, basilar zone expansion with cellular crowding throughout the epithelium, absence of the intermediate zone, and surface flattening confined to the most superficial cells. The nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio is often high and variable, the chromatin is coarse and uneven, and mitotic figures are present through full thickness. The cell size may be markedly increased. Anisocytosis and pleomorphism may be present. (Adapted from WHO, 2015)

Concepts.longName: Lung Squamous Cell Carcinoma In Situ
Concepts.definition: A preinvasive bronchial neoplastic lesion affecting the squamous epithelium. It is characterized by the absence of progression of maturation from base to luminal surface, basilar zone expansion with cellular crowding throughout the epithelium, absence of the intermediate zone, and surface flattening confined to the most superficial cells. The nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio is often high and variable, the chromatin is coarse and uneven, and mitotic figures are present through full thickness. The cell size may be markedly increased. Anisocytosis and pleomorphism may be present. (Adapted from WHO, 2015)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
